name: Bodhi Tree

etymology.derivation: From Sanskrit bodhi (à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¿), from budh (to awaken)

description: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites, representing the axis mundi of Buddhist cosmology.
uses: Meditation - sit beneath bodhi trees to invoke enlightenment energy
Pilgrimage - Bodh Gaya bodhi tree descended from original enlightenment tree
Temple planting - every major Buddhist temple plants bodhi tree
Bodhi leaf amulets - carry dried leaves for spiritual protection
Offerings - water bodhi trees as act of merit and devotion
rituals: Circumambulation - walk clockwise around bodhi trees with prayers
Leaf offerings - placing gold leaf on bodhi leaves as offering
Temple consecration - planting bodhi tree sanctifies temple grounds
Meditation retreats - extended practice under bodhi trees
sacredSignificance: Most sacred tree in Buddhism. Site of Buddha's enlightenment under full moon of Vesak. Represents the possibility of awakening for all beings. Direct descendants of original tree exist worldwide.
culturalContext: Emperor Ashoka's daughter Sanghamitta brought cutting to Sri Lanka in 288 BCE, now oldest verified tree. Bodhi tree cuttings spread Buddhism across Asia. Heart-shaped leaves symbolize Buddha-nature in all beings.
preparationMethods: Medicinal decoction: boil bark in water for digestive issues
Leaf powder: dry leaves, grind to powder for wounds
Poultice: crush fresh leaves for anti-inflammatory application
Sacred offerings: place flowers and incense at tree base
safetyWarnings: fig latex may cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals
